ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live lecture recorded
Also recorded
N/A
Just recorded, synchronous zoom lectures.
None
lecture was recorded
each live lecture was recorded plus we sometimes had breakout room discussions during class
speakers who came
Virtual lecture with virtual office hours.
recorded lecture & live virtual lecture
Live lecture that you can later watch
Live lectures, but they were also recorded.
Assigned textbook readings. Class notes (powerpoint slides) were regularly uploaded.
N/A
n/a
Watched recorded lectures on days where I had to miss the live virtual lectures
n/a
office hours, meetings with professor
It was also recorded.
Live virtual lectures which could also be watched as recorded lectures.
None others. Though some of the assignments were using interesting formats, such as video games.
Also recorded in case students wanted to watch on their own time or rewatch to prepare for exams
Lectures were always recorded, but we were encouraged to attend them live.

Live virtual elections (Prof. preferred students to attend asynchronous lecture).
Lectures were all recorded and posted (what a great thing to have).

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Relationship psychology, attachment theory, relationship dissolution
I learned about the interactions between people and why we interact with others in certain ways.
I learned fascinating topics in the realm of relationships, ranging from romantic relationships to family relationships to friend relationships and more.

Although initially I thought I didn't learn as much about the relationship science as I expected, I realized that it was only because I wasn't in a relationship to start with. After I started dating someone I found the topics we covered in the class extremely relevant and helpful.
I learned a lot about the formation of relationships, what makes them last, and a lot about how people socially interact with all the benefits the individual receives.
everything related to relationships. I learned the basic foundations of the lifetime of relationships. I also learned how to develop a research study.
So much about relationship science. The reasons for why and how relationships develop over time and the intricacies within those relationships

I learned about various theories of romantic and platonic relationships. I learned about why and how people are attracted to each other, how people maintain relationships, and how people get out of relationships.

This course taught me the foundations of relationships of all types: how they begin, what separates some from others, how conflict arises and is handled, etc. It is very much set and discussed in terms of relationship science theory.
i developed insights on how humans develop a relationship and how we sometimes do things unconsciously

This class was a good way of learning the basic methodology of psychology through a very interesting and engaging topic. While there is a disclaimer when taking this that it is not a self-help course, there are certainly skills that can help you to understand relationships in general as well as your own.

Attraction and Relationships covers relationship formation, maintenance and dissolution. Though the course is not meant to be a clinical class, we learned a ton of information that I can apply to my life: what makes you attractive, what makes someone want to stay with you, how to be secure and vulnerable in a relationship, how to keep your relationship from getting stale, what kinds of support to provide, etc.

I also learned to read and make sense of psychology research, and to do my own..
I gained useful knowledge about attraction and relationships
I learned a lot about the relationships in my own life and how to form healthy bonds with other people.
Good relationship advice and personal insight
Foundations of maintaining relationships and the science behind what makes for good relationships of all kinds
You learn about interpersonal relationships, and you learn a lot of advice.

This class illuminated a lot of personal traits, flaws, dynamics and other things going on in my live that maybe I wasn't even aware of. I learned a lot about interpersonal relationships and how to use what we know about psychology to build stronger relationships in different areas.

Everything. This is the best self help class at Yale. It will help you put words and frameworks to your past, present, and future relationships. It wont solve all of your problems, but understanding is the first step in reaching a solution, and this class helps you do just that.
Exposure to psychological studies relating to attachment styles, relationship initiation, conflict resolution, relationship dissolution, and attraction among many others.
How to have healthier relationships and how attraction and relationships form
Great psychology class, good content, very interesting and interactive
basic intro to psychology and a good understanding of relationship theories & lab procedures.
Learned about the different stages in the life of a relationship from attraction & initiation to dissolution
I learned a lot about myself and about how I interact with others in relationships. I loved learning about attachment styles and how to recognize my own behaviors.
I learned about relationships.
Organization and self-discipline developed through attending classes on time and keeping up with all of the assignments.

I learned a ton about myself, my own interactions, my family, my friends, and relationships in general thanks to this course. It helped me re-figure -out my priorities (placing the people I love at the top of my list) in a way that was based on testable science. I had many "aha!' moments during the class, where patterns that I'd noticed in my interactions with others were articulated and clarified, and this too was very valuable.

Knowledge: mechanics of attraction; relationship initiation; maintaining relationships; social support; social cognition; sex; self-growth through relationships; balance of power in relationships; conflict, stresses, and strains
Skills: comprehension of academic papers on psychology; applying concepts to real world situations; relating various psychological theories & concepts together; working with data sets
Insights: how to approach forming and strengthening relationships (friendships, family ties, and romantic endeavors) from a science-based grounding; how to hold constructive arguments/the value of healthy arguing; bow attraction style influences my perspective and actions

Through this course, I learned about the basics of relationships science (such as attraction, self-expansion, and conflict) as well as read about these concepts in research papers. I also learned how to plan a psychology experiment using data obtained by the class.
I learned how important relationships are for our happiness, how they're affected by our social context, and how to try to get the most out of them (gratitude, conflict management, self-expansion).
Better knowledge on relationships and how to incorporate what I learned in the classroom into my own relationships. One of, if not, my favorite class at this school.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Content is very interesting, but the timing for exams and quizzes didn't make sense. The quizzes were meant to be "check-ins" if you read the textbook chapter and watched lecture, but they pulled very small details and you had 12 minutes for 10 questions. They were open note but you ran out of time pretty much every single time because you were searching through your notes so much. The exams were also open note, but there were so many free response questions (with required sourcing) that you would barely finish. The grading is fair in the end, but the exams/quizzes create unnecessary stress.
Strengths: assignments are easy to understand and lectures are interesting.
This course was structured very well, and the material was taught very clearly. The lectures were very engaging, and the videos scattered throughout were always very fun to watch!

Strengths: learned a lot of lessons not only about our relationship but about us human (think personality, social interactions, attachment styles); tests and the final project is fair and interesting since we get to apply what we learned to a real context
Weaknesses: the first half of the lab assignments in my opinion wasn't particularly helpful, so maybe we can get rid of it and spend more time working on our project? Also I think the course could be organized a bit better since we don't follow the chapters outlined by the textbook and jump back and forth a bit too much.
This course was fantastically structured and paced. The biweekly quizzes interspersed with short lab assignments were awesome and relevantly engaged with the lecture material. No weaknesses

strengths: this course was amazing. The lectures were fascinating, and the labs were interesting

weaknesses: none
Strength: Dr. Hirsch is an absolute gem. Take this course with her. I was never once tired during lecture and she was so energizing

Strengths: Course material is SO engaging. Professor Hirsch prefaced the class with the fact that it is not a self-help course, but I think we all learned something about ourselves through the course! The assignments were all incredibly manageable, practical, and fun. Professor Hirsch is also such a cool and down-to-earth professor!
Weaknesses: None!
This course could benefit by having more discussion during lass, but is strong in that lectures really enhance what is learned from the reading.
it was really nice to understand how we work

The subject matter is very interesting and engaging, and from the assignments to the final project, the work never seems tedious or boring. There was not much participation in class between students, but I think this was partially due to the virtual setting.

This is overall a strong course. First order of business: IT IS NOT A GUT! There are many quizzes and labs which means every week I was refreshing my knowledge and learning new things. I didn't mind the workload, but people shopping who think the course will be an easy A are misled.

A strength is the professor and TA, who were engaging, generous and understanding. I enjoyed the assignments (the video game assignment was pretty fun, for a final project, and not too much work). The labs were a bit exhausting and the quizzes could be stressful, but that's just a product of online school more than it was a product of the course itself.

I learned so much!! That's a huge strength. I got into an ~intimate relationship~ this semester and the class totally helped me. Take the course to learn about yourself and others, and how to be in relationships with them. Taking relationships courses can decrease the chance of divorce down the line! (that was in the textbook)

One weakness I might identify is that it wasn't always obvious why the slides fit under the specific heading for the day, or how they fit together (this was more of a problem in some units than others). I guess this is because the professor was stringing together different bits of research and had to connect them somehow, but I guess sometimes I just felt like we jumped around in a way that wasn't always coherently connected. But I understand why and it didn't really impact my experience in the class..

Very interesting. Engaging. One of the best classes I've taken.
Weakness is that sometimes the homework felt like busy work.
Course material is interesting, and the professor is very fun and engaging. It might feel too introductory at times.

This class was great leading to personal insights. It includes a lot of cool studies, data, and short very entertaining videos. I really appreciated the "class lists" that we'd come up with for "ways to keep the excitement alive," or "how to build stronger relationships", or other topics, and Professor Hirsch shared them with the class. The class could be made more interactive like it was at the beginning by promoting the use of the chat function while highlighting that specific questions should be sent to the TA.
Strengths: professor Hirsch. Weaknesses: none.
Very well organized class. The emphasis on learning the content and enjoying the class by reducing the amount of significantly stressful assignments made the class very welcoming and easy to digest.

Lots of busy work when it came to the quizzes and assignments in my opinion, but otherwise the lectures are really engaging! The course is really well organized and its clear shes very passionate about the topic. The prof is an amazing person
Content is very relatable, bi-weekly quizzes helped revise content, good student engagement

strength: super fun and engaging. 
weakness: the quiz format was a little stressful bc of the time constraint.

Strengths: the materials (both lectures and readings) are applicable to everyone's life and very interesting; the lab assignments help you learn how to effectively read psych research papers and teach you how to approach conducting a research yourself; the video game assignment is really creative and fun to do; Prof. Hirsch is a delightful and cool person
Weaknesses: the lecture does move at a relatively slow pace, and the midterms felt really rushed (due to the time it took to find references from slides)

I liked the material of this course but I feel that the assignments could be changed to reflect the style of the course more. I would suggest more interactive assignments to practice engaging with the material in our everyday lives, rather than just regular assignments
There are no sections.
Overall, I believe that the course was taught very well. One thing that could be improved is implementing more breakout rooms for engagement purposes.

Professor Hirsch was caring, attentive, and very engaged. The course was well-organized, and I always knew what we were learning about and why. The professor also did a great job of integrating mid-semester feedback into the course and including more break out rooms to make it feel more personal. 
As for improvements, the labs did feel repetitive and I did not always feel like I was learning much from them besides perhaps a bit about psychological literature. Perhaps these could be changed or alternated occasionally for other assignments.

Strengths:
-Relevance and applicability of material: What you'll learn in this course is applicable to everyone, in a plethora of social contexts. Professor Hirsch also covered the influence of COVID upon relationships, which further emphasized the value and relevance of the material to navigating society.
-Accessibility: This course was my first venture into psychology. However, the material was taught in a comprehensive AND comprehendible manner. It was easy to follow along in lectures. 
-Professor Hirsch and TA Zach Silver: The two were a phenomenal duo! Dr. Hirsch's lectures were engaging and informative. Her passion for the subject was clear to see throughout each lecture, and I was constantly impressed by the clarity and articulation of the material. TA Zach provided very constructive feedback on assignments, and facilitated questions during lectures. Overall, that teamwork ensured a smooth-running and well organized class for the whole semester.
Weaknesses:
-One minute qualm: there was less interaction with peers than I would have liked. Although this aspect of the class improved following mid-semester feedback, I would have enjoyed more polls, breakout rooms, etc. for a more engaging discussion.

Prof. Hirsch hosted an awesome course and I imagine it would have been even better in person. The cut offs for grading were a bit harsh but were given early on so I guess it is fair. Overall, great, great, great course. Great with pacing, lectures, and assignments.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The quizzes to make sure you were keeping up with lectures were nice in theory, but there should have been more time for them.
I think the course allowed for a high level of engagement due to lectures that allowed for active participation. There were also frequent office hours available.
I think that the lectures are fun and breakout rooms are okay, but I can imagine it would be so much more interesting if this is in-person.

Breaking up the multiple choice part of the final into small biweekly quizzes was awesome in that it made sure I stayed constantly engaged with the material rather than cramming it all at once before the midterm and the final, so that practice definitely succeeded.

succeeded: the course was conducted online and the lectures were easily accessible by recordings. I also liked that the multiple choice questions were spread along the whole semester and I think that's the way this course should always be conducted. Also the guest lecturers were amazing!

could be improved: I guess the level of engagement in our breakout rooms could be improved, but this is also a lecture and I understand that we wouldn't be having these discussions under normal circumstances. I think the class was conducted really well.

I think Professor Hirsch did an excellent job adapting the course to the pandemic. She made quizzes open-book, she made the midterm and final less stressful by taking out multiple-choice, she made recorded lectures available, and she had regular office hours. No improvements necessary!
office hours were a great way to ask questions

The course itself was great, and Professor Hirsch's enthusiasm each lecture made the virtual aspects not an issue. The only weakness was that students did not communicate much between one another and attempts to increase participation felt a little forced/awkward.
Professor Hirsch was very understanding, giving us grace days and having office hours. She replied to my emails promptly and was very supportive. She's a great professor!
Having the lectures recorded and open note exams were very helpful.
The flexibility of the course structure. Having live lectures along with recorded lectures and office hours always available was good.
The polls were extremely fun, and the professor made plenty of time available for office hours.
Polls and use of the chat!
It was well adapted to the online course structure, requiring continuous smaller assignments to check for understanding throughout the semester.
As much as I didnt like the biweekly quizzes they did keep me engaged and led me to stay up to date with lecture materials
Online classes worked, but of course it wasn't ideal. Better use of breakout rooms would have been nice
wish more support resources could be provided e.g. office hours/extra review sessions.
Live Zoom lectures and recorded lectures were both easily accessible, and the assignments on canvas have clear instructions

I felt that the workload was a lot. I understand that the professor just broke down the regular workload into smaller chunks, however, I would have preferred less weekly work but instead, have bigger assignments to make up for that.
I think having sections could help.

Enjoyed that lectures were live and kept me accountable to stay on task and attend class rather than watching recorded lectures (although those were helpful as well). Wish that the quizzes showed the answers right away after completing them.

break-out rooms were great, as was the fact that, though lecture was meant to be synchronous, students did not HAVE to attend lecture and could watch later. I attended nearly every lecture synchronously, but really appreciated being able to watch the few that I missed (bc of exhaustion, mental health issues etc) later.

-Canvas modules were organized efficiently
-Canvas site was easy to navigate, especially compared to other courses
-I wish lectures would involve more interaction with peers, such as polls and breakout rooms. The latter half of the semester, after mid-semester feedback, was an improvement in this regard. 
-Questions were moderated by our TA for Prof. Hirsch, such that everyone's opinions were valued

Professor Hirsch really emphasized that even though classes are live, we could still watched the recorded version on Canvas in case we needed a break from Zoom. I feel like that really showcased her caring about her students' well-being.

This course did a great job!! I have no suggestions for further improvement, I think the setup was very accessible and the continuity of either a homework assignment or quiz every Friday made it incredibly easy to remain on-track / on top of our work.
Virtual all year. No comment really. But, the online classes were great and to have guest on was also very cool.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Really interesting material and Professor Hirsch is wonderful.

Yes, I thought the material was incredibly interesting and the course was pretty low-stress since the quizzes and exams were open note. Overall, I think that it was a fun and interesting course that also provides useful insight as to how relationships can be conducted.
Yeah, it's an interesting psych credit that's not too tricky.
Yes! The material was very interesting and the assignments were extremely reasonable. I always looked forward to class. I highly recommend it.
Yes! I learned so many important concepts about how relationships form, are maintained, and dissolve. These concepts are very applicable to our relationships!
You really get to learn a lot about relationships (some of them perhaps intuitive, but it's cool seeing the researchers' methodology)... So why not?
Yes! This course is extremely interesting and will change the way you interact with the people in your life.

yes yes yes! Every single human being should take this course. We are wired for relationships which means they are some of the most important aspects of our lives. There are some basic things we just need to know about our own lives and the way we think. This course gave me invaluable, day-to-day, applicable skills that I still use. You will not regret taking this class. Also, Dr. Hirsch is funny, interesting, and very approachable. She makes the class much more fun.
YES YES YES

Yes!!! Every Yale student should take this course in my opinion. The subject matter is so relevant to all of us as college students looking for fulfillment through relationships. It is also perfect for non-psych majors looking for a nice introductory psych course.
Yes. This course is so fascinating and explores various aspects of relationships which can be very applicable to your own life!
absolutely everyone should take a psychology course
Yes, learned a bunch directly applicable to real-life relationships

Absolutely! This course was a pleasure to take due to the material itself and how enjoyable Professor Hirsch made it. The topic is very useful for everyday life, and this was a great introduction to psychology.

I would recommend Attraction and Relationships to a peer. 

IT IS NOT A GUT. In the way the course is currently formatted, there are weekly assignments that (because I wanted to get an A) pretty much ate up my Fridays. I didn't mind because I really liked the material, but I should note that someone looking for an easy, low workload class should look elsewhere.

I learned so much about relationships and psychology in general, and I think the course *genuinely improved my life*. It was worth it for that reason -- I now believe I'm much better equipped to have healthy friendships and romantic relationships.

Professor Hirsch and Zach were great. Thank you for a great semester~
Yes. This is a great course. Very interesting material that is relevant and applicable to everyday life. Great professor.

Yes definitely! It was only my second psychology course I have taken and found that it was a great introduction into studying relationships! Not challenging concepts to grasp and very applicable to real-world
Yes, everyone should try to take this course before they graduate.
Yes, it was very interesting and engaging
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It is a fun and refreshing psychology elective that is not too stressful.
Yes professor is great. Loved the content. Textbook interesting. Everything was super great.

Yes! It was a great intro psych course for students of any background/year to take and I found it highly enjoyable. The things you learn in this course will be applicable to anyone and hopefully, equip them in maintaining better relationships in their own lives.
Yes, the grading is harsher than you might think, but this course won't stress you out and the professor cares about students' wellbeing.

Yes! I am a junior and this is the best class I have ever taken at Yale so far. Professor Hirsch tells you at the beginning that this is not a self-help course but you will inevitably learn things about yourself and those around you. It was very revealing to me and I have already made changes in my life based on what I learned. It also provides great topics of conversation for you and your friends! And Professor Hirsch is very personal which adds a lot to the class.

100000%. This is the best self help class at Yale. It will help you put words and frameworks to your past, present, and future relationships. It wont solve all of your problems, but understanding is the first step in reaching a solution, and this class helps you do just that. Its like free therapy, and youll want to help others understand these things too. This class helps the greater good of society honestly.

100% This was an amazing course. Prof. Hirsch's radiant personality made each class fun and engaging. Her understanding of us being under a lot of stress made for a perfectly balanced class with enough work to keep students engaged and learning but not too much to drown students in worries about grades. Great class, great prof!
Yes! So relatable and interesting. One of my favourite classes at Yale so far!
yes, if you are interested in psychology / relationship psychology and want to take a fun class to see if you really like psychology

Yes. The materials are applicable and fun, you actually learn from the lab assignments, and Prof. Hirsch is really cheerful and sweet! But this is an introductory psych class, so you might find some parts repetitive if you've taken other psych classes.
yes! I really enjoyed this class and the professor was amazing!
This is one of the most practical classes you can take at Yale-- it is so important to know how to navigate relationships!
Yes!! I loved it! It was incredible and now I'm a psyc major!
Absolutely! Relationships are a huge part of our lives and important to have at least a general understanding on.
Yes! This is a great course for evaluating your own life, priorities, and relationships. I will carry what I learned with me for the rest of my life, I'm sure.

I highly recommend this course to other students! The material itself is fascinating and insightful in understanding the enigma called relationships. In this regard, the course should be mandatory for all Yale students. The course, furthermore, incorporates a plethora of recent research, which greatly informed how the digital age of social media/technology impacts our relationships. That aspect particularly draws so much relevance to our daily lives. Overall, Professor Hirsch was a phenomenal guide to the world of attraction and relationships.

Yes! You get to learn about relationships that backed by empirical evidence and, as a result, reflect on your own relationships in order to make them more fulfilling. It's like the closest thing to therapy without going to therapy.
Absolutely! This was such a fun and easy course, and I still felt like I learned a lot.

HIGHLY RECOMMEND. MAKE SPACE IN YOUR SCHEDULE FOR IT AND IF YOU'RE LUCKY ENOUGH TO GET IN LIKE I WAS, TAKE IT. It's awesome and I think the information I learned has been invaluable and actually applicable in my life. A great introductory psychology course.
